sections.title: What are we comparing?
sections.content:
Both use **have/has**, but:

• **Simple:** I have waited. She has read. (have + past participle)
• **Continuous:** I have been waiting. She has been reading. (have been + -ing)

The choice depends on: **result / how many** vs **how long / visible effect now**.

sections.title: When to use SIMPLE
sections.content:
Use **simple** when you focus on:

• **Result or completion:** I've finished. She's broken her phone.
• **How many:** I've read three books. He's sent five emails.
• **Life experience:** Have you ever been to Japan?
• **Stative verbs** (know, like, have, want): I've known him for years. She's had that car since 2020.

Stative verbs = states, not actions → simple only.

sections.title: When to use CONTINUOUS
sections.content:
Use **continuous** when you focus on:

• **Duration (how long):** I've been waiting for an hour. They've been living here since 2019.
• **Activity in progress or just stopped:** She's been studying all evening.
• **Visible effect now:** Why are your hands dirty? — Because I've been painting.
• **Repeated/temporary activity:** We've been looking for a flat for months.

For, since, all day, lately → often continuous.

sections.title: Quick summary
sections.content:
• Result / how many / stative verb → SIMPLE (have + past participle).
• Duration / how long / visible effect now → CONTINUOUS (have been + -ing).
• When both are possible, the simple stresses the result; the continuous stresses the activity or the time spent.

sections.title: Typical errors
sections.content:
• **Life experience:** Wrong: I never *saw* that film. Right: I've never **seen** that film.
• **Stative verbs:** Wrong: I have *been knowing* him for years. Right: I have **known** him for years.
• **Finished time:** Wrong: I have finished *yesterday*. Right: I **finished** yesterday.
• **How many:** Wrong: I have been *read* three books. Right: I have **read** three books.

Tip: Yesterday, last week → past simple. Up to now, so far, ever → present perfect.

questions.question: We want to emphasise how long an action has been going on. Which form do we usually use?
questions.explanation: Duration (how long) is typically expressed with the present perfect continuous.

questions.question: Which sentence is correct? (Stative verb)

options.a: I have been knowing him for years.
options.c: I have known him for years.
options.d: I am knowing him for years.

questions.explanation: 'Know' is a stative verb; we use the present perfect simple, not the continuous.

questions.question: We want to say how many things are completed. Which form do we usually use?
questions.explanation: Completion and count (how many) are expressed with the present perfect simple.

questions.question: Someone's hands are dirty. We explain this with a recent activity. Which is more natural?

options.d: I have been repairing the bike.

questions.explanation: A visible effect now (dirty hands) is explained with the present perfect continuous.

questions.question: I'm sorry I'm late. I ____ (wait) for the train for almost an hour.
answers: have been waiting
questions.explanation: We focus on how long, so we use the present perfect continuous.

questions.question: She ____ (read) five books so far this summer.
answers: has read
questions.explanation: We focus on how many completed, so we use the present perfect simple.

questions.question: Your hair is wet. ____ you ____ (run) in the rain?
answers: have you been running
questions.explanation: Visible effect now → present perfect continuous.

questions.question: I ____ (know) him since we started high school.
answers: have known
questions.explanation: 'Know' is stative; we use the present perfect simple.

questions.question: They ____ (not sleep) well lately because of the noisy neighbours.
answers: have not been sleeping
haven't been sleeping
questions.explanation: Ongoing situation lately → present perfect continuous.

questions.question: We ____ (look) for a new flat for months.
answers: have been looking
questions.explanation: Duration → present perfect continuous.

questions.question: He ____ (send) ten job applications this week.
answers: has sent
questions.explanation: How many completed → present perfect simple.

questions.question: She ____ (have) that car since 2020.
answers: has had
questions.explanation: 'Have' (possession) is stative; present perfect simple.

questions.question: Wrong: 'I have been loving this new series since the first episode.' Correct the sentence.
answers: I have loved this new series since the first episode.
I have loved this new series since the first episode
questions.explanation: 'Love' is stative; we use the present perfect simple.

questions.question: Wrong: 'I have been having this phone for two years.' Correct the sentence.
answers: I have had this phone for two years.
I have had this phone for two years
questions.explanation: 'Have' (possession) is stative; present perfect simple.

questions.question: Wrong: 'She has been owning that shop since 2019.' Correct the sentence.
answers: She has owned that shop since 2019.
She has owned that shop since 2019
questions.explanation: 'Own' is stative; we use the present perfect simple.

questions.question: Wrong: 'We have been believing in recycling for years.' Correct the sentence.
answers: We have believed in recycling for years.
We have believed in recycling for years
questions.explanation: 'Believe' is stative; present perfect simple.

makesentence.title: Practice: Making sentences (make a full sentence from the cues; use present perfect simple or continuous as appropriate)

answers: I have been waiting for the bus for 20 minutes.
I've been waiting for the bus for 20 minutes.
questions.explanation: Duration → present perfect continuous.

questions.prompt: she / read / three books / this month
answers: She has read three books this month.
She's read three books this month.
questions.explanation: How many completed → present perfect simple.

questions.prompt: you / know / your best friend / since primary school
answers: I have known my best friend since primary school.
I've known my best friend since primary school.
questions.explanation: Stative verb 'know' → present perfect simple.

answers: They have been living in London for five years.
They've been living in London for five years.
They have lived in London for five years.
They've lived in London for five years.
questions.explanation: Both forms are correct here: duration with 'live' can use present perfect simple or continuous.

answers: He has just finished his homework.
He's just finished his homework.
questions.explanation: Completion/result → present perfect simple.

questions.prompt: you / study / all evening (you are tired now)
answers: I have been studying all evening.
I've been studying all evening.
questions.explanation: Duration and visible effect (tired) → present perfect continuous.

makequestion.title: Practice: Making questions (make a question from the cues; use present perfect simple or continuous as appropriate)

answers: How long have they been learning English?
How long have they been learning English
questions.explanation: Duration → present perfect continuous question.

questions.prompt: she / read / books / this year / how many
answers: How many books has she read this year?
How many books has she read this year
questions.explanation: How many completed → present perfect simple question.

questions.prompt: he / out of breath – suggest: exercise
answers: Have you been exercising?
Have you been exercising
questions.explanation: Visible effect → present perfect continuous question.

answers: Have they ever been to Japan?
Have they ever been to Japan
questions.explanation: Experience → present perfect simple question.

answers: How long has she had her car?
How long has she had her car
questions.explanation: Stative 'have' (possession) → present perfect simple question.

questions.prompt: they / do / all morning / what (they look tired)
answers: What have they been doing all morning?
What have they been doing all morning
questions.explanation: Duration and visible effect → present perfect continuous question.
